Commission
Kempton presents suggestions
For changes in Council constitution
reports on
Honor system
On December 16, 1938, a report on
the activities of the Honor Commission from the period between September 25 and December 15 was issued.
According to the statement, progress in the Commission was directed
towards the extension of the Honor
System to every phase of college
life. During that time the Commission succeeded in installing the slip
system in the Engineering school,
the inclusion of the Honor System
in the Teachers College, and also arranged a plan for the night courses
in Technology.

Having completed his proposed
list of recommendations for student
government reform, J Murray Kempton, senior representative in the
body, submitted his work to the council, Dean E W Berry, and Dr Isaiah
Bowman before the Christmas vacation.
Kempton decalred that he based
his recommendations on the theory
that good government rests on the
"good sense of the voting public." He
stated that every college student
should be trained in the "business of
self government," but added that
certain powers were "inalienable
rights of the university."
As a substitute for complete selfgovernment, Kempton recommends:
1. That monthly open meetings of
the student council be held to discuss

As to the success of the slip system,
the Commission announced that not
one slip was turned into them. Upon
this fact they base their claim that
the system has greatly reduced dishonesty in the classrooms. However,
they feel that such a record is too
good, and is probably due to a failure
of the student body to co-operate and
report offenses.
At the beginning of the semester
the Commission printed a phamplet,
"What Price Honor," which familiarized the freshmen with the workings
of the system. In addition, every new
student was obliged to sign a pledge
that he understood the system.
Coinciding with this report, the
Honor Commission also made public
the contents of an investigation of the
freshman class on its opinion of the
operations of the Honor System.
A group of fifty-five, composed
of dormitory men, fraternity and nonfraternity men, and varsity football
men were interviewed. Fifty three
favored the system and two were opposed to it.
When questioned on the slip system, the majority was opposed to
it and gave various reasons
for its position. The report puts
much emphasis on the fact that although the freshmen interviewed
were practically unanimous in their
support of the Honor System, they
are not in favor of the methods employed to enforce it.

MacLeish to give Turnbull poetry lectures
an attempt to define modern poetry
both as it is and as it ought to be.
"The second is a discussion of the
traditional background of modern
poetry—its derivations—and the system by which it is (or isn't) taught.
The third is an examination of audiences and critics including academic
critics.
"The fourth is the evidence of
modern poetry as to the nature of
men in our time—the nature of the
individual. The fifth is poetry in the
political world.
"The last is the evidence of modern
poetry as to our generation's belief,
in our time."
The enthusiasm ran high as the
news of his coming spread around
the university among the faculty and
students acquainted with his work.
Enthusiastic, Dr Hazleton Spencer,
professor of English literature,

as professor of English at the
Breadleaf school of English in Bennington, Vt, heard Mr MacLeish at a
poetry recital one night last summer. He described the poet: "he hadn't
been talking five minutes, when I was
sure that he was not just another
poet, that I was in the presence of
the authentic thing, that, with the
possible exception of Vachel Lindesay
when he was going at his very best,
the MacLeishre recital that night was
the most impressive I ever heard."
At this point Dr Spencer grew lyrical. "As for his poetry, this is no
minor songster twanging an anemic
harp. MacLeish is a really important poet with a wide range a keen intellectual edge and a tremendous passion.

BSA sends bid
to Jan Savitt for
February 23 dance
Resigns post

After six weeks of dickering with
the leading dance bands in the country, Donald Kirkwood, chairman of
the Board of Social Activities, has
announced that the committee has
decided on Jan Savitt for their gala
'big name' band dance.
This announcement was received
with much surprise inasmuch as the
committee had made no mention of
him in their previous statements.
However, Savitt, according to the
music authorities, has a
smooth outfit, and should make a
good choice.
campus

J Murray Kempton

ASU hears
proposals for
Liberal club
J Murray Kempton, member of the
executive committee of the ASU resigned yesterday because he disagreed strongly with the program on
international affairs. He said he was
going to devote his time to a new
approach to campus problems by organizing a Liberal club.
T W McElhiney, non-member of
the ASU suggested that in order to
attain a larger mass movement of
and a new line of approach for
liberals on the campus, as many
members as want to, cut off from the
ASU and join the Liberal club. The
Liberal club will be primarily an investigating organization.
A committee consisting of Margorie Shapiro, Morton Friedenberg,
and Millard Kaufman, of the ASU
will meet the representatives of the
Liberal club, Saturday, at 12.30 to
discuss the matter further.
Millard Kaufman, president of the
ASU, asserted that the fault does not
lie with the National ASU, but with
the ASU on the campus.
"There is no room for two such
organizations on the campus," Friedenberg definitely stated. "It would be
much wiser to combine and then decide upon a new approach."
Because of the present structure
of the National ASU, Kempton felt
that the problem of recruiting freshmen is unsolved and that the ASU
couldn't possibly start with a clean
slate:—
A speaker of the Friends of the
Abraham Lincoln Brigade, believed
that due to the growing unpopularity
of Chamberlain in England, the
weakening of Daladier in France, and
the . possibility of the lifting of the
embargo in America that world
opinion was bound to change in a
month or two in favor of the Loyalists.

Wood awarded medal
The Royal Society of London, donor of the gold Rumford Medal to
men outstanding in the field of
scientific research, announced that
Dr Robert Williams Wood, professor
of experimental physics at the Johns
Hopkins University, has been selected
as the recipient of the award this
year.
Dr Wood was awarded the Rumford medal last November but he was
unable to attend the observance. He
has been devoting most of his time
to the study of physical optics during the past forty years.

Larry Clinton and Artie Shaw, both
riding on a wave of popularity at
present, were the original choices of
the committee. However, each has
skyrocketed his price to $1750,
and the committee felt that the price
was too high to be considered.
A bid was sent to Savitt last week
reported to be $750, but as yet he
has not replied. There is a possibility
that the offer will be refused for
Duke University recently engaged
Savitt's services for $1000.
Should this occur, Kirkwood stated
that either Les Brown or Glenn Miller will be selected. The latter is the
possessor of a fine orchestra and his
popularity has been increasing
steadily.
The committee has gone ahead,
however, with the other necessary
preparations for the affair. The spacious ballroom of th Alcazar has been
chosen as the scene. This decision
was made after the committee investigated all of the suggested places
and found that the Alcazar was the
only locale that would be large
enough to accomodate a large crowd
satisfactorily.
The date of the dance has been
announced as February 23, which
means that there is still sufficient
time to publicize it. It is possible that
the affair will be held as a "Washington Birthday Ball" although it is
scheduled for the following day.
Admission to the dance has been
set at $2.20 per couple. Stags will
probably be admitted for $1.10.
Tickets may be secured in a few days
from the members of the committee.

'Down the Bay
conference planned
The week end of February 4 marks
the date of the annual Down The Bay
conference of the Tri-State area of
Student Christian association,

the

which includes Maryland, Delaware,
and District of Columbia.
The general theme of the conference is "What Does Christianity have
to say about Civil Rights and Responsibilities".

Among the leaders
will be Dr Sherwood Eddy, educator,
Dr Clarence Shedd of Yale Divinity
school, Rabbi Morris Lieberman, of
Madison Avenue synagogue, Baltimore, and Mauritz Hallgreen,
journalist and chairman of the Baltimore Civil Liberties union.
The group will leave Baltimore
Saturday afternoon and sail down the
Chesapeake bay arriving at Hampton
institute on Sunday. The day will be
spent on discussions of various subjects, such as minority problems, freedom of speech, campus and religious
problems.

The group will leave
Hampton institute Sunday night, and
return to Baltimore Monday morning.
Students from all colleges located
in the Tri-State area are attending,
and any students desiring further information should stop in at the Y office in Levering hall and get in contact with Mr Hammaker or some
member of the Y cabinet.

FRIDAY, JANUARY 13, 1939

The full significance of
the Honor Commission's
report to the Student council on the workings of the
honor system at present
does not become apparent
to one until some little time
has been devoted to a detailed study of it. Myriad inferences are possible thereafter, but one or two are
truly worthy of serious consideration.
The statistical report is especially noteworthy. The
freshmen class has been subjected to more diverse
propaganda on the system than any other. In detail
and with system, all phases of operation, all concepts
of basis, all aspects of function were demonstrated
and explained. Results might be expected to be forthcoming. In the freshman class, one might expect the
slip system to work best.
Now a perusal of facts: up to the time of the report, not one slip had been tendered. One of two obvious possibilities is presented: the honor system is
working perfectly, or the system is not—students are
not doing their part in reporting violations.
The figures force us to the latter conclusion. Of
the 55 freshmen interviewed (a good cross-section of
the class) 32 were hesitant or negative as regarded
using the slips, 16 gave no comment, and only 6 were
definitely with the system.
Can it be hoped that any man would report a violation when only 6 of the system's supposedly rabid
supporters will issue even an anonymous warning?
The Commission's plan for cross-sectioning campus
opinion as regards the system is a wise one. The difficulties are many, chief among which is the lack of a
base from which to gauge results. The showings however, should be most interesting when compiled.
We do not believe that the, outlook is a particularlg
dark one—certainly not so dark as might appear at
first blush. And we agree with some Commission members that violations are probably at an all time low.
However, further moves are impossible without an
evaluation of present status. When the students have
voiced their opinions, and the figures are checked,
perhaps we shall know better. Time and work can best
tell.
Meanwhile, we still take our stand for the system.
To our mind it is the only intelligent, mature plan.
But it is, of course, dependent on cooperation.
When the time comes to face the facts squarely,
let us do so.

Honor system:
a gloomy
note

President Roosevelt's
nomination of Professor
Felix Frankfurter for the
Supreme Court last week
brought to all us lovers of
freedom and democracy a
welcome relief from the
now too prevalent notes of bigotry and reaction. Professor Frankfurter has always impressed us with his
liberalism, integrity, and ability to fulfill the position
left open by the death of Justice Cardoza. He is a
mature scholar with a thorough-going understanding
of the traditions, as well as needs, of American life.
Moreover, he has for nearly two years been the leading
choice of lawyers throughout the country for the appointment, as a survey by the American Institute of
Public Opinion has proven. The day after the nomination editorial comment throughout the country hailed
the selection as "best choice".
But the hearings on Frankfurter's nomination
which are being held this week before a judiciary subcommittee of the Senate have filled us with mixed

Daniel in
the lions'
den

emotions of satisfaction and disgust. Of the inquiry
itself we certainly approve wholeheartedly. For the
American public certainly has the right to inquire into
the record and philosophy of a man who is to take a
place in the highest court of the country. And certainly
a man's philosophy and record are important when it
is a question of handing down a decision on our very
vague constitution.
However, the present judiciary inquiry has let
loose a storm of prejudice and bigotry, prejudice and
bigotry that are only allowed voice by the liberalism
they seek to destroy. Presidents and secretaries of the
"save America" type institutions have come before the
Senators and have objected to Professor Frankfurter
on the grounds of communism, alien-mindedness, and
destructive opinions. Subtle objections have been raised
in connection with racial affiliations. *The calibre of
such objectors are well typified by one Mr Redd, national director of the Constitutional Crusaders of
,America. When asked as to meetings, dues, and other
affairs of his organization, Mr Redd stated, "I amithe
whole works myself."
Professor Frankfurter is in Washington now before
the subcommittee. We know that he will make short
work of the absurd, yet serious, charges which have
been laid before him.
There are many things
that make the cause of peace
and democracy look pretty
hopeless these days. And
there is no worse sign of
impending disaster than the
tendency of the very people who have hitherto led in the fight for peace to
climb on the bandwagon of the advocates of a "good
and just" war.
We have at hand a clear example of just that
tendency in the latest convention of the American Student Union. Persons familiar with the student progressive movement will remember the A S U's origin, and
its past leadership in opposing militarism and war.
That leadership is now simply a part of tradition.
For the A S U has clearly demonstrated that it is no
longer interested in the anti-war movement. The
resolutions that have come out of the convention are
bad enough in themselves. They express unequivocal
support of the concept of 'collective security" and of
the program of national defense. The fight against
R 0 T C is abandoned to a few shabby cliches about
democracy. The "peace" resolution is crowned by
point seven, which "welcomes the announcement . . .
of an experimental program in the training of student
pilots and the appropriation of $100,000 . . . We
believe that it should be an integral part of the N Y A
program."
But the weasel words of a formal resolution dont
go far enough in explaining the spirit of the convention. Far more revealing is this statement by Howard
Lee, southern secretary of the Union, which might
have been literally translated from the German of
General Goering: "The people of the South need homes
and schools, but they prefer battleships because of the
world situation. To-day, we need battleships instead!"
The real keynote was struck by Bert Witt, the New
York city secretary in these words: "The time has come
when democracy must be saved not by schools, but by
guns."
It is perfectly plain that no organization whcise leaders can talk like that deserves a place in any genuine
peace movement. The A S U program offers no basis
for cooperation on the part of men of good will, and
is, in point of fact, a very real threat to their hopes.
The fight for peace must go on. But, it can only
be carried on by militant uncompromising liberalism
which smites the strong and succors the weak without
regard for soul-sapping expediency. And such a liberal_
ism is not to be found within hailing distance of the
A S U.

The ASU
goes forth
to war

Time and time again the
editorial columns of the
NEWS-LETTER have been
filled with urgent pleas to
the University for baseball
fields, swimming pools,
reading periods, or other
facilities. Once more we would like to put in a plea
for the swimming team, who find countless obstacles
in their way to swimming success.
But we want to know when the swimming team
comes in on this grand set-up. In previous years the
team has practiced at a 14earby high school, a fitting
place for a college team to practice. This year even
the pool at City college is closed to the mermen, and
they must travel down town for practice. In addition
some practices have to be at night, at the convenience
of the pool owners. Not only is interest killed before it
has a chance to awaken, but men must spend half their
time getting to and from the pool. When schQols are
already prepared for their meets, Hopkins has yet to
have its first practice.
From every angle swimming justifies the propr
support of the school authorities. It is a healthful and
important activity. Despite previous difficulties past
teams have been able to compile favorable, if not
championship records. Certainly, the Hopkins swimming team deserves a break and a new swimming pool.

Those last few idle days gave us
an opportunity for a first-hand examination of Broadway's theatrical offerings for the current season. Unfortunately our choice was limited
so don't blame us if we are too displeased with what composed our bill
of fare.
The Ethel Barrymore theater is
once again the scene of throngs, milling to see Maxwell Anderson's latest
creation, the well-known Knickerbocker Holiday.
With all due credit to the Mr. Anderson, Knickerbocker Holiday, she
ain't what she could be. The only fault
we find with the show is what Mr
Anderson did to it, namely the script.
The lines, gay and clever sometimes,
are artificial always; and the audience can easily see through the dialogue that the author is completely
convinced his own political theories
are correct. It is all well and good
for an author to express his ideas in
his works, and it is not exactly our
place to find fault with these ideas
as ideas, but we can't help saying
that Mr Anderson would do well to
study a little political horse sense;
this often helps to remove the ridiculous from the stage.
The setting of the play is Dutch
New York in the days of "Petey"
Stuyvesant. Walter Huston, the onelegged governor, becomes dictator of
New Amsterdam, and in the course
of his daily decisions decides, viz to
marry Tina Tienhoven (Miss Jean
Madden). Unfortunately, the young
lady loves someone else. The obvious
complications ensue, the New Deal is
knocked, and there we have the play.

Yet, Knickerbocker Holiday is e5ccellent entertainment, thanks to the
efforts of Kurt Well and the cast.
Mr Weill was responsible for the
magnificent music of Eternal Road,
Max Reinhardt's extravaganza of a
few seasons back. Weill again composed an excellent score for Knickerbocker Holiday; the songs are clever
and tuneful and fit the rapidly changing moods of Anderson's script.
Walter Huston, heading the cast,
is inimitable as Stuyvesant. He dances
gaily about the stage on his silver
leg, acting a part most unexpected
of Othello and Dodsworth. We don't
want to appear presumptuous but
there might be a musical comedy future for the eminent Mr Huston.
Credit too belongs to the supporting
cast in the persons of Miss Madden,
Richard Kollman, and Ray Middleton.
Shakespeare seems to be taking
one on the familiar chin\ in the farce
now populating the Alvin Theater,
namely, The Boys from Syracuse.
The bard of our language suffers his
famous Comedy of Errors to undergo
certain undignified alterations to become another of those entertaining
George Abbott productions.
Please permit us a scoop. One of
the most promising plays of the season will have its premiere right here
at the Johns Hopkins Playshop on
February 13th. Claire and Paul Sifton
have written a play about socialized
medicine, The Doctors, certainly a
pertinent topic and one of interest to
many in our midst. Immediately after
its engagement here, the play is scheduled for New York.

BALTIMORE

Between
snatches
of Physics,
Philosophy, and Psycholgy, Larry
Clinton has ,been a welcome relief to
your much-harassed reporter. You
see, Hopkins is en route to exams
(Haven't you heard?) and music is
still a soothing balm to the proverbial savage beast. If you haven't
tried it before, there's nothing like
reading history to the tune of Artie
Shaw's "Softly as in a Morning Sunrise". The wild beating of the drums
provides a perfect background for
the fall of the Bastille, and Mr Shaw's
clarinet would surely be enough to
call the most peaceful jitterbug to
arms. "Softly as in a Morning Sunrise" is backed by "Copenhagen" and
that lovely old city is pretty well
done up brown in the hands of this
popular master of the clarinet.
Several other new tunes have been
revived and rejuvenated by the swing
master; and while they go hack
pretty far, it seems as though the
music of Mozart and Bethoven has
thus far been saved from desecration.
Larry Clinton has a brand new arrangement of "Temptation" which is

something to hear. The tune was

To turn to some platters which

music. Of the sweeter songs which
are now most in demand, "Deep in a
Dream" and "They Say", have joined
hands with "The Umbrella Man",
and this enjoying trio is heading the
field in a typical photo-finish.

On December 16, 1938, a report on
the activities of the Honor Commission from the period between September 25 and December 15 was issued.
According to the statement, progress in the Commission was directed
towards the extension of the Honor
System to every phase of college
life. During that time the Commission succeeded in installing the slip
system in the Engineering school,
the inclusion of the Honor System
in the Teachers College, and also arranged a plan for the night courses
in Technology.

Having completed his proposed
list of recommendations for student
government reform, J Murray Kempton, senior representative in the
body, submitted his work to the council, Dean E W Berry, and Dr Isaiah
Bowman before the Christmas vacation.
Kempton decalred that he based
his recommendations on the theory
that good government rests on the
"good sense of the voting public." He
stated that every college student
should be trained in the "business of
self government," but added that
certain powers were "inalienable
rights of the university."
As a substitute for complete selfgovernment, Kempton recommends:
1. That monthly open meetings of
the student council be held to discuss

As to the success of the slip system,
the Commission announced that not
one slip was turned into them. Upon
this fact they base their claim that
the system has greatly reduced dishonesty in the classrooms. However,
they feel that such a record is too
good, and is probably due to a failure
of the student body to co-operate and
report offenses.
At the beginning of the semester
the Commission printed a phamplet,
"What Price Honor," which familiarized the freshmen with the workings
of the system. In addition, every new
student was obliged to sign a pledge
that he understood the system.
Coinciding with this report, the
Honor Commission also made public
the contents of an investigation of the
freshman class on its opinion of the
operations of the Honor System.
A group of fifty-five, composed
of dormitory men, fraternity and nonfraternity men, and varsity football
men were interviewed. Fifty three
favored the system and two were opposed to it.
When questioned on the slip system, the majority was opposed to
it and gave various reasons
for its position. The report puts
much emphasis on the fact that although the freshmen interviewed
were practically unanimous in their
support of the Honor System, they
are not in favor of the methods employed to enforce it.

an attempt to define modern poetry
both as it is and as it ought to be.
"The second is a discussion of the
traditional background of modern
poetry—its derivations—and the system by which it is (or isn't) taught.
The third is an examination of audiences and critics including academic
critics.
"The fourth is the evidence of
modern poetry as to the nature of
men in our time—the nature of the
individual. The fifth is poetry in the
political world.
"The last is the evidence of modern
poetry as to our generation's belief,
in our time."
The enthusiasm ran high as the
news of his coming spread around
the university among the faculty and
students acquainted with his work.

professor of English literature,

as professor of English at the

poetry recital one night last summer. He described the poet: "he hadn't

sure that he was not just another
poet, that I was in the presence of
the authentic thing, that, with the
possible exception of Vachel Lindesay
when he was going at his very best,
the MacLeishre recital that night was
the most impressive I ever heard."

BSA sends bid

Resigns post

After six weeks of dickering with
the leading dance bands in the country, Donald Kirkwood, chairman of
the Board of Social Activities, has
announced that the committee has
decided on Jan Savitt for their gala
'big name' band dance.
This announcement was received
with much surprise inasmuch as the
committee had made no mention of
him in their previous statements.
However, Savitt, according to the
music authorities, has a
smooth outfit, and should make a
good choice.

J Murray Kempton

ASU hears
proposals for
Liberal club
J Murray Kempton, member of the
executive committee of the ASU resigned yesterday because he disagreed strongly with the program on
international affairs. He said he was
going to devote his time to a new
approach to campus problems by organizing a Liberal club.
T W McElhiney, non-member of
the ASU suggested that in order to
attain a larger mass movement of
and a new line of approach for
liberals on the campus, as many
members as want to, cut off from the
ASU and join the Liberal club. The
Liberal club will be primarily an investigating organization.
A committee consisting of Margorie Shapiro, Morton Friedenberg,
and Millard Kaufman, of the ASU
will meet the representatives of the
Liberal club, Saturday, at 12.30 to
discuss the matter further.
Millard Kaufman, president of the
ASU, asserted that the fault does not
lie with the National ASU, but with
the ASU on the campus.
"There is no room for two such
organizations on the campus," Friedenberg definitely stated. "It would be
much wiser to combine and then decide upon a new approach."
Because of the present structure
of the National ASU, Kempton felt
that the problem of recruiting freshmen is unsolved and that the ASU
couldn't possibly start with a clean
slate:—
A speaker of the Friends of the
Abraham Lincoln Brigade, believed
that due to the growing unpopularity
of Chamberlain in England, the
weakening of Daladier in France, and
the . possibility of the lifting of the
embargo in America that world
opinion was bound to change in a
month or two in favor of the Loyalists.

Wood awarded medal
The Royal Society of London, donor of the gold Rumford Medal to
men outstanding in the field of
scientific research, announced that
Dr Robert Williams Wood, professor
of experimental physics at the Johns
Hopkins University, has been selected
as the recipient of the award this
year.
Dr Wood was awarded the Rumford medal last November but he was
unable to attend the observance. He
has been devoting most of his time
to the study of physical optics during the past forty years.

Larry Clinton and Artie Shaw, both
riding on a wave of popularity at
present, were the original choices of
the committee. However, each has
skyrocketed his price to $1750,
and the committee felt that the price
was too high to be considered.
A bid was sent to Savitt last week
reported to be $750, but as yet he
has not replied. There is a possibility
that the offer will be refused for
Duke University recently engaged
Savitt's services for $1000.
Should this occur, Kirkwood stated
that either Les Brown or Glenn Miller will be selected. The latter is the
possessor of a fine orchestra and his
popularity has been increasing
steadily.
The committee has gone ahead,
however, with the other necessary
preparations for the affair. The spacious ballroom of th Alcazar has been
chosen as the scene. This decision
was made after the committee investigated all of the suggested places
and found that the Alcazar was the
only locale that would be large
enough to accomodate a large crowd
satisfactorily.
The date of the dance has been
announced as February 23, which
means that there is still sufficient
time to publicize it. It is possible that
the affair will be held as a "Washington Birthday Ball" although it is
scheduled for the following day.
Admission to the dance has been
set at $2.20 per couple. Stags will
probably be admitted for $1.10.
Tickets may be secured in a few days
from the members of the committee.

'Down the Bay
conference planned
The week end of February 4 marks
the date of the annual Down The Bay
conference of the Tri-State area of
Student Christian association,

the

which includes Maryland, Delaware,
and District of Columbia.
The general theme of the conference is "What Does Christianity have
to say about Civil Rights and Responsibilities".

Among the leaders
will be Dr Sherwood Eddy, educator,
Dr Clarence Shedd of Yale Divinity
school, Rabbi Morris Lieberman, of
Madison Avenue synagogue, Baltimore, and Mauritz Hallgreen,
journalist and chairman of the Baltimore Civil Liberties union.
The group will leave Baltimore
Saturday afternoon and sail down the
Chesapeake bay arriving at Hampton
institute on Sunday. The day will be
spent on discussions of various subjects, such as minority problems, freedom of speech, campus and religious
problems.

The group will leave
Hampton institute Sunday night, and
return to Baltimore Monday morning.
Students from all colleges located
in the Tri-State area are attending,
and any students desiring further information should stop in at the Y office in Levering hall and get in contact with Mr Hammaker or some
member of the Y cabinet.

FRIDAY, JANUARY 13, 1939

The full significance of
the Honor Commission's
report to the Student council on the workings of the
honor system at present
does not become apparent
to one until some little time
has been devoted to a detailed study of it. Myriad inferences are possible thereafter, but one or two are
truly worthy of serious consideration.
The statistical report is especially noteworthy. The
freshmen class has been subjected to more diverse
propaganda on the system than any other. In detail
and with system, all phases of operation, all concepts
of basis, all aspects of function were demonstrated
and explained. Results might be expected to be forthcoming. In the freshman class, one might expect the
slip system to work best.
Now a perusal of facts: up to the time of the report, not one slip had been tendered. One of two obvious possibilities is presented: the honor system is
working perfectly, or the system is not—students are
not doing their part in reporting violations.
The figures force us to the latter conclusion. Of
the 55 freshmen interviewed (a good cross-section of
the class) 32 were hesitant or negative as regarded
using the slips, 16 gave no comment, and only 6 were
definitely with the system.
Can it be hoped that any man would report a violation when only 6 of the system's supposedly rabid
supporters will issue even an anonymous warning?
The Commission's plan for cross-sectioning campus
opinion as regards the system is a wise one. The difficulties are many, chief among which is the lack of a
base from which to gauge results. The showings however, should be most interesting when compiled.
We do not believe that the, outlook is a particularlg
dark one—certainly not so dark as might appear at
first blush. And we agree with some Commission members that violations are probably at an all time low.
However, further moves are impossible without an
evaluation of present status. When the students have
voiced their opinions, and the figures are checked,
perhaps we shall know better. Time and work can best
tell.
Meanwhile, we still take our stand for the system.
To our mind it is the only intelligent, mature plan.
But it is, of course, dependent on cooperation.
When the time comes to face the facts squarely,
let us do so.

Honor system:
a gloomy
note

President Roosevelt's
nomination of Professor
Felix Frankfurter for the
Supreme Court last week
brought to all us lovers of
freedom and democracy a
welcome relief from the
now too prevalent notes of bigotry and reaction. Professor Frankfurter has always impressed us with his
liberalism, integrity, and ability to fulfill the position
left open by the death of Justice Cardoza. He is a
mature scholar with a thorough-going understanding
of the traditions, as well as needs, of American life.
Moreover, he has for nearly two years been the leading
choice of lawyers throughout the country for the appointment, as a survey by the American Institute of
Public Opinion has proven. The day after the nomination editorial comment throughout the country hailed
the selection as "best choice".
But the hearings on Frankfurter's nomination
which are being held this week before a judiciary subcommittee of the Senate have filled us with mixed

Daniel in
the lions'
den

emotions of satisfaction and disgust. Of the inquiry
itself we certainly approve wholeheartedly. For the
American public certainly has the right to inquire into
the record and philosophy of a man who is to take a
place in the highest court of the country. And certainly
a man's philosophy and record are important when it
is a question of handing down a decision on our very
vague constitution.
However, the present judiciary inquiry has let
loose a storm of prejudice and bigotry, prejudice and
bigotry that are only allowed voice by the liberalism
they seek to destroy. Presidents and secretaries of the
"save America" type institutions have come before the
Senators and have objected to Professor Frankfurter
on the grounds of communism, alien-mindedness, and
destructive opinions. Subtle objections have been raised
in connection with racial affiliations. *The calibre of
such objectors are well typified by one Mr Redd, national director of the Constitutional Crusaders of
,America. When asked as to meetings, dues, and other
affairs of his organization, Mr Redd stated, "I amithe
whole works myself."
Professor Frankfurter is in Washington now before
the subcommittee. We know that he will make short
work of the absurd, yet serious, charges which have
been laid before him.
There are many things
that make the cause of peace
and democracy look pretty
hopeless these days. And
there is no worse sign of
impending disaster than the
tendency of the very people who have hitherto led in the fight for peace to
climb on the bandwagon of the advocates of a "good
and just" war.
We have at hand a clear example of just that
tendency in the latest convention of the American Student Union. Persons familiar with the student progressive movement will remember the A S U's origin, and
its past leadership in opposing militarism and war.
That leadership is now simply a part of tradition.
For the A S U has clearly demonstrated that it is no
longer interested in the anti-war movement. The
resolutions that have come out of the convention are
bad enough in themselves. They express unequivocal
support of the concept of 'collective security" and of
the program of national defense. The fight against
R 0 T C is abandoned to a few shabby cliches about
democracy. The "peace" resolution is crowned by
point seven, which "welcomes the announcement . . .
of an experimental program in the training of student
pilots and the appropriation of $100,000 . . . We
believe that it should be an integral part of the N Y A
program."
But the weasel words of a formal resolution dont
go far enough in explaining the spirit of the convention. Far more revealing is this statement by Howard
Lee, southern secretary of the Union, which might
have been literally translated from the German of
General Goering: "The people of the South need homes
and schools, but they prefer battleships because of the
world situation. To-day, we need battleships instead!"
The real keynote was struck by Bert Witt, the New
York city secretary in these words: "The time has come
when democracy must be saved not by schools, but by
guns."
It is perfectly plain that no organization whcise leaders can talk like that deserves a place in any genuine
peace movement. The A S U program offers no basis
for cooperation on the part of men of good will, and
is, in point of fact, a very real threat to their hopes.
The fight for peace must go on. But, it can only
be carried on by militant uncompromising liberalism
which smites the strong and succors the weak without
regard for soul-sapping expediency. And such a liberal_
ism is not to be found within hailing distance of the
A S U.

The ASU
goes forth
to war

Time and time again the
editorial columns of the
NEWS-LETTER have been
filled with urgent pleas to
the University for baseball
fields, swimming pools,
reading periods, or other
facilities. Once more we would like to put in a plea
for the swimming team, who find countless obstacles
in their way to swimming success.
But we want to know when the swimming team
comes in on this grand set-up. In previous years the
team has practiced at a 14earby high school, a fitting
place for a college team to practice. This year even
the pool at City college is closed to the mermen, and
they must travel down town for practice. In addition
some practices have to be at night, at the convenience
of the pool owners. Not only is interest killed before it
has a chance to awaken, but men must spend half their
time getting to and from the pool. When schQols are
already prepared for their meets, Hopkins has yet to
have its first practice.
From every angle swimming justifies the propr
support of the school authorities. It is a healthful and
important activity. Despite previous difficulties past
teams have been able to compile favorable, if not
championship records. Certainly, the Hopkins swimming team deserves a break and a new swimming pool.

Those last few idle days gave us
an opportunity for a first-hand examination of Broadway's theatrical offerings for the current season. Unfortunately our choice was limited
so don't blame us if we are too displeased with what composed our bill
of fare.
The Ethel Barrymore theater is
once again the scene of throngs, milling to see Maxwell Anderson's latest
creation, the well-known Knickerbocker Holiday.
With all due credit to the Mr. Anderson, Knickerbocker Holiday, she
ain't what she could be. The only fault
we find with the show is what Mr
Anderson did to it, namely the script.
The lines, gay and clever sometimes,
are artificial always; and the audience can easily see through the dialogue that the author is completely
convinced his own political theories
are correct. It is all well and good
for an author to express his ideas in
his works, and it is not exactly our
place to find fault with these ideas
as ideas, but we can't help saying
that Mr Anderson would do well to
study a little political horse sense;
this often helps to remove the ridiculous from the stage.
The setting of the play is Dutch
New York in the days of "Petey"
Stuyvesant. Walter Huston, the onelegged governor, becomes dictator of
New Amsterdam, and in the course
of his daily decisions decides, viz to
marry Tina Tienhoven (Miss Jean
Madden). Unfortunately, the young
lady loves someone else. The obvious
complications ensue, the New Deal is
knocked, and there we have the play.

Yet, Knickerbocker Holiday is e5ccellent entertainment, thanks to the
efforts of Kurt Well and the cast.
Mr Weill was responsible for the
magnificent music of Eternal Road,
Max Reinhardt's extravaganza of a
few seasons back. Weill again composed an excellent score for Knickerbocker Holiday; the songs are clever
and tuneful and fit the rapidly changing moods of Anderson's script.
Walter Huston, heading the cast,
is inimitable as Stuyvesant. He dances
gaily about the stage on his silver
leg, acting a part most unexpected
of Othello and Dodsworth. We don't
want to appear presumptuous but
there might be a musical comedy future for the eminent Mr Huston.
Credit too belongs to the supporting
cast in the persons of Miss Madden,
Richard Kollman, and Ray Middleton.
Shakespeare seems to be taking
one on the familiar chin\ in the farce
now populating the Alvin Theater,
namely, The Boys from Syracuse.
The bard of our language suffers his
famous Comedy of Errors to undergo
certain undignified alterations to become another of those entertaining
George Abbott productions.
Please permit us a scoop. One of
the most promising plays of the season will have its premiere right here
at the Johns Hopkins Playshop on
February 13th. Claire and Paul Sifton
have written a play about socialized
medicine, The Doctors, certainly a
pertinent topic and one of interest to
many in our midst. Immediately after
its engagement here, the play is scheduled for New York.

BALTIMORE

Between
snatches
of Physics,
Philosophy, and Psycholgy, Larry
Clinton has ,been a welcome relief to
your much-harassed reporter. You
see, Hopkins is en route to exams
(Haven't you heard?) and music is
still a soothing balm to the proverbial savage beast. If you haven't
tried it before, there's nothing like
reading history to the tune of Artie
Shaw's "Softly as in a Morning Sunrise". The wild beating of the drums
provides a perfect background for
the fall of the Bastille, and Mr Shaw's
clarinet would surely be enough to
call the most peaceful jitterbug to
arms. "Softly as in a Morning Sunrise" is backed by "Copenhagen" and
that lovely old city is pretty well
done up brown in the hands of this
popular master of the clarinet.
Several other new tunes have been
revived and rejuvenated by the swing
master; and while they go hack
pretty far, it seems as though the
music of Mozart and Bethoven has
thus far been saved from desecration.
Larry Clinton has a brand new arrangement of "Temptation" which is

something to hear. The tune was

"Louise" and she has come back with

To turn to some platters which
have fire without the flame, we see
that Maxine Sullivan has recorded
two ballads which have not yet died.
They are "Night and Day" and "It
Ain't Necessarily So". Miss Sullivan
and these songs being what they are,
further explanation may be withheld.
Oh, death, where is thy sting?—is
that a record! To mention that prolific Mr Clinton again, I find that he
has dished up a would-be sequel to
"Reverie". It is "Lullabye" from the
opera "Jacelyn" and it should enjoy
a little success now that we seem to
be in the midst of a period of sweet
music. Of the sweeter songs which
are now most in demand, "Deep in a
Dream" and "They Say", have joined
hands with "The Umbrella Man",
and this enjoying trio is heading the
field in a typical photo-finish.
